awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN)
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative effort between scientists from 5 western universities whose research is focused on the study of the emissions from western U.S. wildfire plumes.  A sampling strategy will be employed using a wide range of instrumentation on the NSF/NCAR C-130 aircraft to study atmospheric chemical reactions occurring in wildfire plumes. This field campaign is being conducted in collaboration with related campaigns supported by other agencies: the FIREX campaign by NOAA and the FIREChem mission by NASA. These campaigns are planned to take place in the late summer of 2018. 

The Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN) campaign addresses scientific questions related to fixed nitrogen, absorbing aerosols, and cloud activation and chemistry in wildfire plumes. This research focuses on the first day of plume evolution following initial emissions. The chemistry and microphysics occurring during this time impacts the partitioning of reactive nitrogen, alters cloud chemistry and nucleation, and largely determines aerosol scattering and absorption.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the chemistry in western wildfire smoke has major ramifications for air quality, nutrient cycles, weather, and climate. Burn conditions combined with the first several hours of atmospheric processing are major drivers of the eventual air quality and climate significance of wildfire smoke. This project systematically characterized the emissions and evolution of western U.S. wildfire plumes.

Intellectual Merit

The evolution, speciation and partitioning of reactive nitrogen is central to within-plume free radicals, downwind oxidant production, and the amount and eventual form of nitrogen deposited to ecosystems. Normalized excess mixing ratios of reactive nitrogen species have now been reported for > 20 western U.S. wildfires. A key finding is that more than 50% of emissions are in reduced form even for large fires sampled during periods with flaming fronts during mid-afternoon conditions. For similar fuel types, the emissions of ammonia are of similar magnitude to lab-based estimates; however, nitrogen oxide emission factors appear to be smaller. We have produced the most comprehensive analysis of the fate of reduced and oxidized reactive nitrogen in western U.S. wildfire plumes to date.

To this point, there was no basis for implementing parameterization of biomass burning particles as ice nucleating particles (INPs) into cloud and climate models. We have produced the first estimates of INPs from wildfire emissions. The project has also produced the first estimate of how western wildfire smoke influences the properties of cumulus clouds. On average the smoke-influenced clouds sampled during WE-CAN had 5 times more droplets, and droplets that were half the size of clouds were not influenced by smoke. WE-CAN data is being used to improve parameterizations within the Regional Atmospheric Modeling System (RAMS). RAMS is a set of computer programs that simulate the atmosphere for weather and climate research and for numerical weather prediction. 

WE-CAN and FIREX-AQ served as the first airborne deployments of near real-time water-soluble brown carbon measurements. WE-CAN also allowed for the development of a method to reliably sample gas-phase ammonia from research aircraft at a high time response in polluted conditions. This latter instrumental advance has implications for sampling other ammonia sources including those from agriculture and urban areas. 

Broader Impacts

This project promoted graduate and undergraduate learning via several activities. The observations were largely collected and analyzed by graduate students. Graduate students gained experience with sophisticated instrumentation, data interpretation, and forecasting in this context. The project also included the development of a graduate course focused on airborne observations that was offered simultaneously to graduate students across multiple institutions. Undergraduate students were involved in the project through the NSF Earth System Modeling and Education Institute (ESMEI) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. Undergraduate women from the NSF PROGRESS (PROmoting Geoscience Research, Education and SuccesS) mentoring program met the project team and visited the research aircraft. The project enhanced the infrastructure for research by piloting new techniques for the measurement of brown carbon and gas-phase ammonia from an airborne platform. There has been broad dissemination of this work through a large number of publications and presentations at national meetings. The team has organized sessions at national meetings focused on the chemistry of wildfire smoke. They have also contributed to national-scale interdisciplinary meetings aimed at summarizing knowledge on wildfire smoke and identifying research gaps. The project has had larger scientific and societal benefits outside atmospheric chemistry because the data has been used to identify which hazardous air pollutants deserve attention in wildfire smoke and has aided in estimating U.S. wide exposure to these pollutants. The field campaign team has also promoted diversity by piloting promising interventions to reduce harassment in field campaign settings.
